data.name: GoCD
data.description: [GoCd](https://www.gocd.io/) is a open-source Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery System. The native support for pipelines, in house expertise(few of the members literally built the tool) and better visualizations compared to other tools made GoCD our tool of choice at Indix.

data.name: Snap CI
data.description: [Snap CI](https://www.snap-ci.com/)

data.name: Travis CI
data.description: Travis CI is a cloud based CI offering seamless integration with Github. The need for a CI tool for all the opensource projects @ Indix aptly filled, does the job well and is free.

data.name: Concourse CI
data.description: A CI tool with first-class support for containers and a fairly simple UI. The container support makes it a good CI tool to assess. [More ...](https://concourse.ci/index.html)

data.name: Jenkins
data.description: [Jenkins](https://jenkins.io/) is the CI tool which comes with a lot of features and plugins that enable it to be a unified build and automation tool. [Jenkins](https://jenkins.io/) wasn't build from the ground up to support Continuous Delivery, hence lacked native support for pipelines and visualizations that we were able to get from GoCD.

data.name: Ansible
data.description: [Ansible](https://www.ansible.com) is an open-source automation engine that automates cloud provisioning, configuration management, and application deployment. The agent-less architecture which enables us to create automation and manage configurations with very little effort makes us to adopt Ansible as our CM tool. Also it comes with other features like provisioning and deployment automation.

data.name: Chef-solo
data.description: [Chef-solo](https://docs.chef.io/chef_solo.html) is a command that executes chef-client in a way that does not require the Chef server in order to converge cookbooks. Similar to [ansible](https://www.ansible.com) we like the agent-less architecture and the in-house expertise made it easier to adopt Chef-solo.

data.name: Chef-server
data.description: [Chef](https://www.chef.io/chef) is a CM tool that enables you to manage small to large scale datacentres on and off the cloud with its client server model where the client reaches out to the server periodically to sync its configurations. Being a client sever model it has a lot of moving parts and comes with a host of challenges like Server bottleneck, Single point of failure, complicated architecture hence we put it on hold.

data.name: Terraform
data.description: [Terraform](https://www.terraform.io) is a tool for building, changing, and versioning infrastructure safely and efficiently. [Terraform](https://www.terraform.io) can manage existing and popular service providers as well as custom in-house solutions. The ability to create immutable infra backed with good community support encouraged us to try [Terraform](https://www.terraform.io) at Indix.

data.name: Cloudformation
data.description: [AWS](https://aws.amazon.com) [CloudFormation](https://aws.amazon.com/cloudformation) provides an easy way to create and manage a collection of related [AWS](https://aws.amazon.com) resources, provisioning and updating them in an orderly and predictable fashion. The obvious problem that we had with this tool was that it was only [AWS](https://aws.amazon.com) specific, and the complicated JSON required to create templates didn't help either hence we put it on hold.

data.name: Bind
data.description: [BIND](https://www.isc.org/downloads/bind) is open source software that enables you to publish your Domain Name System (DNS) information on the Internet, and to resolve DNS queries for your users. At Indix we were in favor of a managed DNS service hence we put [Bind](https://www.isc.org/downloads/bind) on hold.

data.name: R53
data.description: [Amazon Route 53](https://aws.amazon.com/route53) is a highly available and scalable cloud Domain Name System (DNS) web service. We liked [R53](https://aws.amazon.com/route53) from the outset as it made DNS management easy and reliable hence we adopted it as our choice of tool for DNS.

data.name: Capistrano
data.description: A remote server automation and deployment tool written in [Ruby](https://www.ruby-lang.org/en). At Indix we are using [Ansible](https://www.ansible.com) for both CM and provisioning so it made it simpler to choose the same over [Capistrano](http://capistranorb.com) as [Capistrano](http://capistranorb.com) didn't bring anything new to the table than what [Ansible](https://www.ansible.com) had to offer in terms of deployments.

data.name: Splunk
data.description: [Splunk](https://www.splunk.com) is a log management tool that can be used to monitor and analyze the data collected. The data collected can then be used to generate graphs, reports, alerts and dashboards. At Indix we just need a simple and cost-effective tool for log management and [Splunk](https://www.splunk.com) was too costly for us hence we put it on hold.

data.name: Loggly
data.description: [Loggly](https://www.loggly.com) is a cloud based log management tool where you simply install a client on your server and the log is shipped to a central unit for management. At Indix, we adopted [loggly](https://www.loggly.com) as it was economical, well managed, cloud based and had a decent functionality for analytics

data.name: ELK
data.description: [ElasticSearch Logstash Kibana](https://www.elastic.co/videos/introduction-to-the-elk-stack) is a combination of open source tools which can used for log management. Its one of the commonly used tools for log management in the industry. At Indix we were looking for a managed service and [ELK](https://www.elastic.co/videos/introduction-to-the-elk-stack) stack has a complex architecture and needs effort to manage in house, and for all the effort you put in its fairly costly to build, there is no licensing cost but running a HA/ Scalable stack of [ELK](https://www.elastic.co/videos/introduction-to-the-elk-stack) wasn't cost effective hence we put it on hold. Also, in [Loggly](https://www.loggly.com) - defining alerts as and when required is simple, can be done via UI.

data.name: Docker
data.description: [Docker](https://www.docker.com) is synonymous to containers and we at Indix like the ease of use and portability that it offers and have adopted it for Dev/CI environments. The kernel compatibility issues that [Docker](https://www.docker.com) had didn't give sufficient confidence to adopt it across all Production environments yet hence its put on hold.

data.name: Rkt
data.description: [Rkt](https://github.com/coreos/rkt) is a pod-native container engine for Linux. It is composable, secure, and built on standards. The focus on security and a composable architecture were the key reasons why we at Indix wanted to assess this tool.

data.name: CoreOS
data.description: With Container Linux and Kubernetes, [CoreOS](https://coreos.com) provides the key components to secure, simplify and automatically update your container infrastructure. We at Indix, wanted to try out [CoreOS](https://coreos.com) as it offered an ecosystem of container specific tools that scales well and offers great flexibility.

data.name: CentOS
data.description: The [CentOS](https://www.centos.org) Linux distribution is a platform derived from the sources of Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL). We liked the more frequent updates that come as part of Ubuntu rather than the slower updates in case of [Centos](https://www.centos.org). Also the user community in case of Centos is not as huge as Ubuntu, hence we put it on hold.

data.name: Ubuntu
data.description: [Ubuntu](https://www.ubuntu.com) is one of the most popular debian Linux distros out there. We at Indix like the active community support, frequent updates and arguably the best package management.

data.name: Mesos
data.description: [Apache Mesos](http://mesos.apache.org) abstracts CPU, memory, storage, and other compute resources away from machines (physical or virtual), enabling fault-tolerant and elastic distributed systems to easily be built and run effectively. We at Indix use [Mesos](http://mesos.apache.org) to manage our resources for the features it provides.

data.name: Marathon
data.description: A container orchestration platform for [Mesos](http://mesos.apache.org) and DC/OS. We use [marathon](https://mesosphere.github.io/marathon) to manage application deployments in mesos.

data.name: Kubernetes
data.description: [Kubernetes](https://kubernetes.io) is an open-source system for automating deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications. We at Indix wanted to try [Kubernetes](https://kubernetes.io) as it offers great scalability and flexibility.

data.name: Mesosphere DCOS
data.description: Mesosphere Enterprise DC/OS includes everything you need to elastically run containerized apps and data services in production. We wanted to assess this tool as it paired well with [mesos/marathon](https://mesosphere.github.io/marathon) that we are already using.

data.name: AWS
data.description: [AWS](https://aws.amazon.com) is a public IAAS provider that provides a rich set of features to host your infrastructure in the public cloud. At Indix, we liked the scale, reliability and flexibility that [AWS](https://aws.amazon.com) had to offer. Also being the leading IAAS provider in the market it has good integration with the best tools for provisioning and automation required to manage a tool like this.

data.name: Google Cloud
data.description: [Google's version of the IAAS](https://cloud.google.com), offering similar tools and feature set as other providers in the market. Google seems to offer better data-processing and data-flow compared to [AWS](https://aws.amazon.com) hence we at Indix wanted to assess it.

data.name: Azure
data.description: [Azure](https://azure.microsoft.com/en-in) is the IAAS offering from Microsoft. We find [Azure](https://azure.microsoft.com/en-in) not as matured and refined as [AWS](https://aws.amazon.com) and hence we decided to put it on hold at Indix.

data.name: BareMetal DC
data.description: We don't want the overhead of infrastructure management by ourselves and also to lose the flexibility of scaling on demand.

data.name: Private Cloud
data.description: We are also assessing the possibility of an in house private Cloud in DC as it would offer more visibility and control over public IAAS providers.

data.name: Letsencrypt
data.description: [Letâ€™s Encrypt](https://letsencrypt.org) is a free, automated, and open Certificate Authority. Features like more granular and selective controls towards authorization, easy automation and no cost made it the tool of choice at Indix.

data.name: AWS Certificate Manager
data.description: [AWS Certificate Manager](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/acm/latest/userguide/acm-overview.html) makes it easy to provision, manage, and deploy SSL/TLS certificates on AWS-managed resources. Since all our infra is in AWS and this being a free tool offering features like automated renewal we adopted it at Indix.

data.name: MultiFactor Authentication
data.description: MFA is implemented in AWS, mail and github as we at Indix give security utmost importance.

data.name: Bash
data.description: Since we are a Linux only environment [Bash](https://www.gnu.org/software/bash) is the default scripting tool. We use it for all low level system based activities and also to create small integrations between other autmoation tools.

data.name: Python
data.description: [Python](https://www.python.org) is a OOP language that lets you work quickly and integrate systems more effectively. For the tasks that Bash can't handle we look at [Python](https://www.python.org) since there is nothing that Python can't handle. In house expertise also makes it the language of choice compared to [Ruby](https://www.ruby-lang.org/en).

data.name: Ruby
data.description: A dynamic, open source OOP language with a focus on simplicity and productivity. It has an elegant syntax that is natural to read and easy to write. Python already filled the need for the high level language that [Bash](https://www.gnu.org/software/bash) couldn't fill and since we work a lot on Ansible(which is built in python) integrations were also lot more easier with [python](https://www.python.org) hence we put [ruby](https://www.ruby-lang.org/en) on hold.

data.name: Go
data.description: [Go](https://golang.org) is an open source programming language that makes it easy to build simple, reliable, and efficient software.

data.name: ECMAScript 2015 (ES6)
data.description: ECMAScript 2015 (initially referred to as ES6) was finalized in June 2015 and introduces new syntax for writing complex applications (including classes & modules) and is generally a sorely needed upgrade to the language. Though browser support for ES6 is still incomplete, ES6 features can be used with the [Babel](https://babeljs.io/) transpiler.

data.name: CoffeeScript
data.description: [CoffeeScript](http://coffeescript.org/){:target='_blank'} is a programming language that transcompiles to JavaScript. It adds syntactic sugar in an effort to enhance JavaScript's brevity and readability.
data.opinion: Indix started using CoffeeScript in 2015. The primary reason was to reduce boiler plate code that we were writing due to JavaScript idiosyncarnies. Example - [Pros and cons of CoffeeScript](http://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/questions/72569/what-are-the-pros-and-cons-of-coffeescript). It did improve our productivity during the time of usage and multiple apps based out of CoffeeScript run in production. But as of 2017 Q1, we no longer use it because ES2015/ES6 solves a lot of the problems that CoffeeScript was trying to solve without drastic syntax changes. Migration of existing apps to ES6 is in backlog and will be picked on case-by-case basis.

data.name: TypeScript
data.description: TypeScript is a free and open-source programming language developed and maintained by Microsoft. It is a strict superset of JavaScript and adds static typing to the language. At Indix, apps which need to communicate to micro-services via APIs benefit vastly from static types.

data.name: React JSX
data.description: JSX is a JavaScript syntax extension that looks similar to XML. It is more familiar for casual developers such as designers and doesn't alter the benefits of HTML.

data.name: Polymer
data.description: Polymer is a HTML language to build fast, beautiful, and interoperable web components. Web Components are a set of standards currently being produced by Google engineers as a W3C specification that allow for the creation of reusable widgets or components in web documents and web applications. Polymer looks potentially valueable.

data.name: HAML
data.description: HAML (HTML abstraction markup language) is based on one primary principle - markup should be beautiful. HAML accelerates and simplifies template creation. Some of the production apps at Indix are already using HAML.

data.name: LESS
data.description: LESS is a CSS pre-processor; it extends the CSS language, adding features that allow variables, mixins, functions and many other techniques that allow you to make CSS that is more maintainable, themeable and extendable. Indix is a major consumer of [Bootstrap](http://getbootstrap.com/) and ever since Bootstrap made SASS as its default, Indix has put LESS on hold.

data.name: SASS
data.description: Sass is an extension of CSS and defines a clean structured way of writing CSS by allowing to modularize CSS snippets while offering a whole slew of features which are practised in javascript environment. Features like varables, external imports, functions and extensibility allow to experience the benefits of modular patterns. Given its advantages, Indix actively adopts Sass for styling its web apps.

data.name: PostCSS
data.description: PostCSS was launched as a method to use JavaScript for CSS processing. PostCSS on its own is simply an API, which, when used with its vast ecosystem of plugins, offers powerful abilities. Because of its promising custom plugins and tools for transforming styles, Indix is actively assessing the language.

data.name: Yeoman
data.description: [Yeoman](http://yeoman.io/){:target='_blank'} helps you to kickstart new apps by providing generator templates with frameworks of developer's choice. Any developer who want to quickly bootstrap a web app can pick the web frameworks of his/her choice and let Yeoman generate the scaffolding of project structure.
data.opinion: Indix picked upon yeoman generators like [React-starter-kit](https://github.com/kriasoft/react-starter-kit/tree/yeoman-generator){:target='_blank'} and have active production app running on it. Indix is as well actively assessing the huge ecosystem of generators and will use them as need arises. Any non-front-end-engineer who want to quickly prototype an app, Yeoman is the preferred choice to bootstrap at a quicker pace.

data.name: Material Design
data.description: Google created [Material Design](https://material.io/guidelines/){:target='_blank'} principles with the intention to create a visual language and a single unified experience across platforms.
data.opinion: Indix tried Material Design in one of its internal apps and is actively following its associated frameworks. The themes and the user experience are seamless and being actively adopted to Google applications. Indix is in wait and watch mode for extensive adoption of the technique, as the concept gives flexibility only to override the theme and colors of the visual elements, but not the feel and behaviour. Indix will move the technique to assess once Material design provides extensive overriding capabilities to fit the technique to Indix's visual theme and behaviour.

data.name: Typed Javascript
data.description: Javascript being loosely typed, gives the developer flexibility to play with data types. While in some cases, this flexibility is useful, most of the cases, apps need to be strict-typed in-order to communicate with the backend. TypeScript is one of the framework, Indix is actively __Assessing__ for any further apps.

data.name: Express
data.description: Express is a [Node.js](https://nodejs.org/en/) web application framework with many HTTP utility methods and act as middleware for building web applications. Many utilities and an active community make Express an easy choice for middleware for all Node.js apps at Indix.

data.name: Meteor
data.description: Meteor is a highly-opiniated platform to build web, mobile and desktop apps with a same set of javascript code and connects database to end user's screen with high set of integrations. Lesser code and tighter integrations looks promising, which makes it a platform worth assessing at Indix.

data.name: Koa
data.description: Koa is an alternate to Express with better support for better error handling & middleware cascading. Koa is built using ES6 generators (with Koa v2 dropping around April 2017 with `async`/`await` support) and is more lightweight, which makes it a candidate for assessment at Indix.

data.name: Node.js
data.description: Node.js is a JavaScript runtime built on top of Chrome's V8 JavaScript engine. It's lightweight, efficient, event-driven model and the extensive community of plugins makes Node.js a heavily used runtime at Indix.

data.name: Io.js
data.description: Io.js was a fork of Node.js. Because of its benefits of adopting the performance improvements of V8 and [Semver](http://semver.org)-based release cycles, Indix used Io.js for a brief period, but then, put it on hold when it was decided to merge it back with Node.js.

data.name: Backbone.js
data.description: Backbone.js provides a Model-View-Collection structure to web applications and helps with utilities to build APIs RESTful. Indix was an early adopter of Backbone.js due to to its minimalistic MVC model, but with Redux unidirectional flow of events and virtual-dom updates, Indix has put Backbone on hold.

data.name: AngularJS 1.0
data.description: Angular was developed by Google to build dynamic web pages with support for data-binding and templates on client side. Indix evaluated AngularJS for some internal projects, but put the 1.0 version on hold after the release of Angular 2.0.

data.name: AngularJS 2.0
data.description: Angular 2.0 is rewritten in TypeScript and has made Components first class citizens. Simplified directives & support for Web sockets are some features which look promising. Indix is currently assessing possibilities of its use.

data.name: React
data.description: React is the View part of the MVC model. It abstracts the DOM away from the app and implements one-way data flow, as an alternate to Angular's two-way binding. It's benefits of composable components and intelligent state maintenance has made it the default client-side framework at Indix.

data.name: Redux
data.description: Redux is a state container for JavaScript apps and helps the app to behave consistently. Redux helps to plug-in immutability to a web app state, resulting in lesser bugs in the code. Due to these advantages, Indix uses Redux in combination with React.

data.name: MobX
data.description: MobX is a state management system that is somewhat similar to Redux, but is less opiniated. It makes state management very simple by transparently applying functional reactive programming (TFRP). Here at Indix, we use it in some React-based projects.

data.name: Ember.js
data.description: Ember.js is based on the MVC pattern with support for [Handlebar](http://handlebarsjs.com/) templates. It promises improved developer productivity and has common utilities to build apps faster. Indix is assessing Ember and will possibly use the framework based on needs.

data.name: Polymer
data.description: Polymer is the adopter of [Web components](http://webcomponents.org) and Indix evaluated it during it's early beta stage. Indix is continuously assessing Polymer and since web components use new or still-developing browser capabilities, Polymer promises greater community adoption in the future.

data.name: Bootstrap 3.x
data.description: Bootstrap is the most popular HTML framework with in-built support for responsive design. Indix was an early adopter of Bootstrap and it is our default framework for designing web-apps.

data.name: Bootstrap 4.x
data.description: Bootstrap v4, still in [Alpha]((https://v4-alpha.getbootstrap.com/)), is a major revision to our favourite CSS framework. It introduces Flexbox support (finally!) and includes many new welcome changes like a `rem`-based grid, [cards](http://v4-alpha.getbootstrap.com/components/card/) and built-in Tether! Being an Alpha release, it is bound to break; but we have begun using Bootstrap v4 for a few internal projects.

data.name: Foundation
data.description: Foundation is an alternative to Bootstrap with lightweight code and built with better understanding of web accessibility. With more form controls out of the box and flexible navigation patterns, Indix has adopted Foundation for some of its projects.

data.name: Material UI
data.description: With React being in adoption, and Google introducing Material UI guidelines, The Material UI HTMl/CSS framework provides a combination of the two. Indix uses Material UI framework in some of it's projects and is assessing the possibilities of adopting more of Material UI themes and guidelines.

data.name: Lodash
data.description: Lodash provides utilities to act and manipulate JSON data. It has flexibility to work both in browser as well as server side. Indix uses Lodash in majority of the apps, due to its extensive set of utilities.

data.name: Underscore.js
data.description: Underscore in an utility similar to lodash, but given that Lodash has grown into a more consistent superset of Underscore preferred framework for NodeJS apps, we have Underscore on hold for now.

data.name: Isomorphic Fetch
data.description: Isomorphic Fetch helps to write single piece of code for AJAX calls, which can work both on the server as well as the client side. It is based on latest ES6 features and Indix has adopted the library in some of its projects.

data.name: jQuery
data.description: jQuery is the lodash for DOM. With React providing all the functionalities of jQuery, Indix has put jQuery on hold and will possibly use it when need arises.

data.name: RxJS
data.description: Reactive eXtensions of JavaScript is a set of libraries for composing asynchronous and event-based programs using observable collections and query operations. It acts like lodash for DOM events and allows developer to chain a sequence of operations both on data as well as DOM events. Indix has tried RxJS in one of its apps and continues to follow the community in recent upgrades.

data.name: Socket.IO
data.description: Socket.IO is a library that provides comprehensive support for WebSockets, enabling us at Indix to build realtime web applications. It is isomorphic (meaning we can use it on both the client & the server sides) and supports automatic reconnection and disconnection detection, making for a very robust and reliable WebSocket library.

data.name: NPM
data.description: Node provides scripts directive with enough packages to build, compile, watch, live-reload and test with pre and post-hooks. It has packages to support streaming of these tasks, which make NPM a good enough tool to assess for build automation.

data.name: Yarn
data.description: Written by Facebook as an alternative to NPM, [Yarn](https://yarnpkg.com/) is a package manager. Yarn uses a deterministic algorithm to quickly flatten dependencies, resulting in a completely flat dependency tree and *very fast* installation times. Yarn is also a drop-in replacement for NPM (well, almost) and so migrating should be relatively painless.

data.name: Gulp.js
data.description: Gulp uses the power of node streams to automate the build workflow. Its plethora of plugins and active community makes Gulp the build tool of choice at Indix.

data.name: Grunt
data.description: Grunt is a config-based build automation tool as opposed to Gulp which is code based. Grunt's' performance in terms of file processing is comparatively worse to Gulp, and hence Indix has it on Hold.

data.name: Mocha
data.description: Mocha is a unit testing Javascript testing framework, with support for asynchronous tests, coverage reports, handling uncaught errors and timeouts. These flexibilities make Mocha the main testing framework at Indix.

data.name: Chai
data.description: Chai is a [BDD](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior-driven_development) assertion library and easily pairable with Mocha. Indix efficiently uses the chaining capabilities of Chai's assertions.

data.name: Jest
data.description: Jest is built by developers of React and provides powerful mocking functions as default behaviour. It virtualizes Javascript environment using [JSDOM](https://github.com/tmpvar/jsdom) and has utilities to test varied DOM behaviour. Due to slow performance aspects of Jest, Indix has put the framework in trial mode and is actively following the community, looking for performance improvements.

data.name: Istanbul
data.description: Istanbul is a code coverage measurement tool from the YUI team and offers coverage for statement, branches and functions. It's multiple report formats and support as both a command line tool as well as a library makes Istanbul the favourite coverage tool at Indix.

data.name: Jasmine
data.description: Jasmine was one of the earliest Javascript testing tools and comes as an package with in-built assertion utilities. Jasmine doesn't come with a test runner, while Mocha does. Indix has put Jasmine on hold, with Mocha + Chai being adopted.

data.name: Nock
data.description: Nock is a HTTP mocking and expectation library and provides utilities to mock RESTful APIs. Since much of the apps at Indix are API-based, we have actively tried nock in some of our projects.

data.name: WebdriverIO
data.description: WebdriverIO helps to write functional tests. It allows to write a series of asynchronous commands which is run on a headless browser and couples well with Mocha+Chai combination. Indix is using WebdriverIO as the default choice of tool for functional testing of web apps.

data.name: Bower
data.description: Bower is a package manager for all client-side libraries. With NPM as Indix's' choice for package management, we have put Bower on hold.

data.name: Browser Stack
data.description: Browser Stack provides a plethora of browser testing capabilities across different OS. Being a market leader in that domain, Indix has adopted Browser Stack as the default browser testing tool.
